contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox philosopher | region = Western Philosophy | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] | image = | caption = | signature = | name = Knud Ejler Løgstrup | birth_date = 2 September 1905 | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | death_date = {{dda|df=yes|1981|11|20|1905|9|2}} | death_place = | school_tradition = [[Continental philosophy]] | main_interests = [[Philosophy of religion]], [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|Phenomenology]], [[Ethics (philosophy)|Ethics]] | influences = [[Martin Heidegger]], [[Martin Luther|Luther]], [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], [[Søren Kierkegaard|Kierkegaard]], [[Hans Lipps|Lipps]], [[Stephen Toulmin|Toulmin]] | influenced = [[Zygmunt Bauman]] | notable_ideas = the 'ethical demand,' the 'sovereign expressions of life' }} '''Knud Ejler Løgstrup''' (1905–1981) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[philosophy|philosopher]] and [[theology|theologian]]. Løgstrup was an [[Ethical intuitionism|ethical intuitionist]] who was critical of rule-based [[ethics]] of the type advocated by [[Immanuel Kant]]. In other words, he disliked ethical systems which try to determine basic [[moral]] laws. Løgstrup mentions philosopher [[Stephen Toulmin]]'s example of an everyday situation: "I have borrowed a book from John and the question is now, why should I give it back today as I promised him?", Toulmin asks in order to derive more general moral rules. But if I give John back his book because "I should always keep my promises" or because of the more general rule "I should never lie", I treat him as a means; this is unethical, as well. In the 1930es Løgstrup was a part of the [[Tidehverv]] movement in Danish theology which at the time espoused a [[dialectical theology]], he left the movement in the early 1950s. Morality is not about rules, but about the so-called 'sovereign expressions of life'. All men have an [[Intuition (knowledge)|intuitive]] feeling of right and wrong. 'Sovereign expressions of life' includes feelings and actions as open speech, [[Trust (social sciences)|trust]], [[compassion]], [[mercy]], and [[love]]. These phenomena are intrinsically good. A good example is open speech. Even when secret police are searching an apartment, the people living there cannot help but speak with the police sergeant, because it feels intuitively natural to do so. Moral laws are only substitutes for intuition in situations where these intuitive feelings fails to lead to action. For instance, the [[ethic of reciprocity|Golden rule]] is a substitute for [[compassion]]. So, Løgstrup takes the opposite point of view to Kant, who believed that moral laws are the only truly moral basis for action, and that natural desires can never be moral. ==Translated works== * Knud Løgstrup.
